Highlights

  • Workday Named a Leader Again in Gartner Magic Quadrant for Financial Planning (Published 2025-12-04)

    Workday's fourth consecutive leadership recognition by Gartner reflects its established position as an AI-forward SaaS platform excelling at integrating agentic automation and scenario modeling for finance transformation. Gartner points to Workday's ability to provide robust AI-driven planning and data reliability, strengthening its appeal for clients facing complex compliance and visionary transformation needs. This independently validates the credibility of Workday's agentic approach and offers Deloitte a market-differentiating narrative for intelligent finance modernization, particularly relevant for regulated industries and clients prioritizing transparency and trust in AI deployment.

  • Workday President to Speak at Barclays 23rd Global Technology Conference (Announced 2025-12-04)

    Workday's participation at Barclays' global tech conference positions it at the vanguard of the rapidly evolving conversation about AI governance, risk, and extensibility in enterprise SaaS. Executive-level visibility at such high-profile industry events often foreshadows upcoming product strategy and market engagement directions. For Deloitte, this is a timely intelligence opportunity, helping to anticipate Workday client concerns and to proactively shape solution offerings that align with the latest executive messaging.

  • AWS Doubles Down on Enterprise AI with New Model Integrations (Published 2025-12-05)

    AWS's re:Invent announcements, which include new AI chips, agent orchestration controls, and trusted deployment mechanisms, intensify the arms race for enterprise AI in the SaaS space. AWS's focus on secure, compliant, and open model integration sets a new benchmark for agentic interoperability. This directly impacts Deloitte’s deployment strategies: integrating AWS controls and agent orchestration concepts will be crucial in client architectures that span Workday, SAP, Amazon, and Microsoft clouds.

  • Snowflake and Workday Deepen Partnership for AI-Driven Enterprise Integration (Published 2025-12-03)

    Snowflake's expanded partnership with Workday tackles critical legacy barriers to real-time, multi-domain analytics in HR and finance by enabling AI-driven, bidirectional agentic data flows. This brings to life advanced use-cases in people analytics, risk management, and financial scenario planning. The extended solution multiplies the value for Deloitte-led transformations, supporting delivery of unified agent and data service architectures for clients pursuing broad-based AI automation.

  • Gartner’s 2025 ITDR Report: Okta Cited as ITDR Platform Leader (Published 2025-12-02)

    Okta’s recognition as an ITDR leader by KuppingerCole and Gartner foregrounds the rising importance of agent-identity management as AI-driven digital workers proliferate across hybrid ecosystems. Identity security now extends to AI agents within enterprise audit, risk, and compliance models—reinforcing Workday’s and Deloitte’s emphasis on federated, trustworthy SaaS deployments. This elevation of agent identities shapes the requirements for end-to-end, risk-controlled SaaS transformation strategies.

What changed this week

The last week marks a crystallization of agentic AI as a core competency in leading SaaS and cloud ecosystems. Workday solidifies its agentic leadership with external validation from Gartner, fresh executive-level industry advocacy, and deeper strategic integration with data and identify providers (Snowflake, Okta). AWS’s powerful advances in AI orchestration and trust controls raise expectations for open, secure, and scalable agentic solutions in the cloud. The common thread is convergence on agent lifecycle management—governed, integrated, and auditable across hybrid platforms—signaling to enterprise clients that secure, extensible, multi-agent architectures are no longer aspirational but essential. For Deloitte, this environment unlocks differentiated advisory and delivery opportunities if we can rapidly enable our teams with reference architectures, compliance playbooks, and client education aligned with these developments.

Competitive Watch

  • AWS: New chips, agent controls, cross-cloud integration at re:Invent raises the bar for secure, scalable agent deployment and interoperability. Deloitte must invest in multi-cloud agent orchestration to maintain advisory leadership as clients increasingly demand SaaS, data cloud, and IaaS convergence for AI agents.
  • Snowflake: Expanded real-time agentic integration with Workday sets new expectations for agent-to-agent data flows and composable analytics in HR and finance, advancing the argument for unified data and agent governance. Deloitte’s architectures must reflect this for next-gen AI-powered client solutions.
  • Okta: ITDR Leader recognition by Gartner/KuppingerCole further validates identity-anchored security for digital and human worker agents—a risk and compliance priority in Deloitte-led SaaS transformations.

Enablement

  • Workday Agent System of Record Fundamentals: Resource at https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-02-11-The-Next-Generation-of-Workforce-Management-is-Here-Workday-Unveils-New-Agent-System-of-Record
    Outcome: Consultative teams can clearly articulate how Workday’s model supports lifecycle, access, and compliance needs for digital agents.
  • Snowflake-Workday Agentic Integration Architectures: Resource at https://www.snowflake.com/en/blog/workday-partnership-ai-driven-enterprise
    Outcome: Teams enable next-gen analytics and HR/finance automation by leveraging agent-driven, cross-platform data flows.
  • Multi-Cloud Agent Security and Compliance: Resource at https://www.okta.com/ko-kr/blog/industry-insights/okta-kuppingercole-2025-itdr-leader
    Outcome: Security and compliance leads architect robust agent identities to meet evolving regulatory demands.

Actions for Next Week

  • Develop cross-functional playbooks for integrating Workday agents with AWS, Snowflake, and Okta.
  • Create collateral reflecting Workday and Gartner narratives for client conversations.
  • Run briefings on AWS’s new policy controls for trusted AI agents.
  • Update Deloitte’s solution accelerators to leverage new agentic capabilities from Workday and Snowflake.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Fragmented agent governance as clients blend SaaS and cloud increases compliance blind spots.
    Mitigation: Advocate for unified system-of-record and federated identity architectures using Workday, Okta, and Snowflake.
  • Risk: Overwhelming innovation pace may slow adoption in risk-averse sectors.
    Mitigation: Lead with Gartner validation and Deloitte’s risk frameworks to reassure and guide clients.

All Sources

  • Workday Named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Financial Planning Software
  • Workday President to Present at Barclays 23rd Annual Global Technology Conference on December 11, 2025
  • At re:Invent, AWS strikes back in AI with new chips, models
  • Snowflake and Workday Accelerate the AI-Driven Enterprise
  • Okta Named ITDR Leader in 2025 KuppingerCole and Gartner Reports
  • The Next Generation of Workforce Management is Here–Workday Unveils New Agent System of Record

Produce a comprehensive JSON object that matches the schema I will give you exactly.

- TODAY_ET = 2025-12-06
- Include items published or updated between these dates.

RESEARCH SCOPE
Analyze developments related to Agentic AI in SaaS ecosystems — with Workday as the anchor — over the past week. 
Include:
- Workday AI advancements, partnerships, and feature releases.
- Competitive moves across major HCM/ERP vendors.
- GSI and boutique consultancy thought leadership, whitepapers, or partnership news.
- Analyst and press coverage (Forrester, Gartner, IDC, Bloomberg, Reuters, etc.).
- Regulatory, governance, or ethical AI considerations impacting enterprise HR systems.
- Patterns across vendor ecosystems and how they reshape client conversations.

WRITING EXPECTATIONS
- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:
  - The essence of the update.
  - The implications for Workday and broader SaaS players.
  - The impact on Deloitte’s Workday practice, offerings, or positioning.
- Include a <h3>“What changed this week”</h3> section synthesizing shifts and sentiment.
- Highlight interconnections among Workday, competitors, GSIs, and boutiques.
- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

FORMATTING RULES
- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).
- `html_body` must use semantic HTML (<h2>, <h3>, <p>, <ul>, <li>, <a href="...">) with absolute URLs.
- Section order: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Limit HTML body to ~45 KB.
- `plain_text_body` = clean text summary with URLs visible.

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2025-12-06.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2025-12-05T08:03 to 2025-12-06T08:03); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2025-11-29…2025-12-06; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

AWS and Okta have upped the stakes in trusted agent deployment (AWS) and digital identity (Okta), raising client expectations for cross-cloud, compliant agent or AI worker deployments. Deloitte’s strength now depends on how quickly it can orchestrate unified agent governance, identity, and data architectures across these converging SaaS and cloud platforms.\\n\\nCOMPETITIVE WATCH\\n- AWS: Advanced AI and agent orchestration features (https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/05/reinvent-aws-strikes-back-ai-new-chips-models-story) push SaaS vendors to support open agent integration, driving demand for Deloitte’s multi-cloud strategies.\\n- Snowflake: Deeper agentic integration with Workday (https://www.snowflake.com/en/blog/workday-partnership-ai-driven-enterprise) enables more advanced analytics and agent-driven HR/finance workflows.\\n- Okta: Validation as ITDR leader (https://www.okta.com/ko-kr/blog/industry-insights/okta-kuppingercole-2025-itdr-leader) drives enterprise need for robust agent and user identity management in SaaS and hybrid cloud deployments.\\n\\nENABLEMENT\\n- Workday Agent System of Record Fundamentals: https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-02-11-The-Next-Generation-of-Workforce-Management-is-Here-Workday-Unveils-New-Agent-System-of-Record (Outcome: Explain agent lifecycle management for compliance).\\n- Snowflake-Workday Agentic Integration Architectures: https://www.snowflake.com/en/blog/workday-partnership-ai-driven-enterprise (Outcome: Design cross-platform agentic data flows).\\n- Multi-Cloud Agent Security and Compliance: https://www.okta.com/ko-kr/blog/industry-insights/okta-kuppingercole-2025-itdr-leader (Outcome: Architect agent identity models for regulatory needs).\\n\\nACTIONS FOR NEXT WEEK\\n- Develop agentic integration playbooks (Workday-AWS, Snowflake, Okta)\\n- Synthesize Gartner/Workday leadership for client decks\\n- Train teams on AWS’s new agent policy controls\\n- Map Deloitte accelerators to reflect new Snowflake integration\\n\\nRISKS & MITIGATIONS\\n- Risk: Fragmented agent governance increases compliance risks. Mitigation: Advocate for unified, federated identity and agent architecture using Workday, Okta, Snowflake.\\n- Risk: Innovation pace can overwhelm clients, stalling adoption. Mitigation: Leverage Gartner validation and Deloitte's risk frameworks to build client confidence.\\n\\nALL SOURCES\\n- Workday Named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Financial Planning Software: https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-12-04-Workday-Recognized-as-a-Leader-in-2025-Gartner-R-Magic-Quadrant-TM-for-Financial-Planning-Software-for-Fourth-Year-in-a-Row\\n- Workday President to Present at Barclays 23rd Annual Global Technology Conference: https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-12-04-Workday-President-to-Present-at-Barclays-23rd-Annual-Global-Technology-Conference-on-December-11,-2025\\n- AWS at re:Invent: https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/05/reinvent-aws-strikes-back-ai-new-chips-models-story\\n- Snowflake and Workday Partnership: https://www.snowflake.com/en/blog/workday-partnership-ai-driven-enterprise\\n- Okta ITDR Leader: https://www.okta.com/ko-kr/blog/industry-insights/okta-kuppingercole-2025-itdr-leader\\n- Workday’s Agent System of Record: https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-02-11-The-Next-Generation-of-Workforce-Management-is-Here-Workday-Unveils-New-Agent-System-of-Record\\n\"\n}",

While NetSuite has embedded AI capabilities into workflows for years, he explains, Next represents a quantum leap — contextual, conversational, agentic, composable AI becoming an extension of operations, not separate tools.\n\n### AI woven into everyday business operations [...] Most enterprise AI today gets bolted on through APIs and conversational interfaces.\n\nNetSuite Next operates differently.       "url": "https://www.alation.com/blog/what-is-data-integration-types-use-cases-challenges/",
      "title": "8 Common Data Integration Issues and How to Address ...",
      "content": "Effective integration breaks down silos, enabling real-time insights, streamlined workflows, and the advanced AI use cases that depend on high-quality, trusted data. When integration falls short, organizations risk inconsistent reporting, operational inefficiencies, and stalled AI initiatives—making a strong integration strategy essential for any modern data-driven enterprise.\n\n## Key takeaways [...] Blocked AI initiatives: AI and machine learning models require large data sets of high-quality and integrated data for training. Data silos and poor data quality prevent organizations from building such comprehensive training data sets. Semantic inconsistencies cause models to learn incorrect patterns, while an inability to integrate real-time data prevents the deployment of critical AI applications like fraud detection. [...] Organizations today collect data from countless sources—internal databases, CRM systems, cloud SaaS platforms, social media channels, and IoT devices. Yet this data often arrives in different formats, at varying quality levels, and spread across disconnected systems. The result is persistent data silos that slow operations, limit visibility, and hinder strategic decision-making. According to recent industry analyses, failed data integration projects cost enterprises millions each year in lost",

Most workers get several hours leisure time even on workdays, before and after work.\n\nImage 5: Kacy.H\n\n#### Kacy.H\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nChina\n\n Chinese \n\n   Dec 8, 2018\n\n   \n\n   Contact us\n   Terms and rules\n   Privacy policy\n   Help\n   RSS",

    {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] WordReference.com Language Forums\n\n Rules/Help/FAQ\n Members \n\n  Current visitors\n Interface Language\n\nMenu\n\nLog in\n\nRegister\n\nInstall the app\n\nHow to install the app on iOS\n\nFollow along with the video below to see how to install our site as a web app on your home screen.\n\nNote: This feature may not be available in some browsers.\n\n English Only\n English Only [...] So, you might say 'As Wednesday was a work day, I couldn't stay up late on Tuesday'; or 'I always spend the working day dreaming of holidays'.",
      "score": 0.075619064,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "jour ouvré / jour ouvrable | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/jour-ouvré-jour-ouvrable.607089/",
      "content": "workday is AE, then (I didn't know that)  \n   \n I believe we would only say a working day for a day when you you choose or are assigned to work (if you don't have a standard Mon-Fri work assignment).  \n   \n Next week Saturday is a working day (or workday) for me, so I can't play golf then. Si j'ai bien compris l'exemple donné par staarkali, ça pourrait être l'équivalent de jour ouvré. [...] Well the link clears up this debate for me, which I had until now not clearly understood  \n   \n jour ouvré in AE is business day, vs jour ouvrable, workday  \n   \n The other thread gives the example of receiving a ticket after x jours ouvrés (càd sans compter les samedis, dimanches ou autres jours fériés). In AE we would say \"your ticket will be sent x business days after it is ordered.\" (i.e., not counting Saturdays, Sundays or legal holidays)\n\n#### Nicomon\n\n##### Senior Member [...] I also say workday, for jour ouvrable, though I don't mind working day. But jour ouvrable suivant = next business day. I thik business day is mostly used for commerce and finance.   \n   \n Now - as already suggested - there is a difference to be made between jour ouvré and jour ouvrable.   \n   \n As found in the GDT, under jour ouvrable  \n> Définition :  \n>  Jour de la semaine qui est normalement consacré au travail ou aux activités professionnelles et qui n'est pas un jour férié.",

    {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"\n\n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"\n\n  more commonly \"working day\".\n\n   Image 9: Agree\n\nReactions:futursimple\n\nImage 10: KHS\n\n#### KHS [...] ##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\n USA - English L1 \n\n   Dec 30, 2014\n\n   \n\n   Contact us\n   Terms and rules\n   Privacy policy\n   Help\n   RSS\n\nCommunity platform by XenForo®© 2010-2025 XenForo Ltd.\n\nBack\n\nTopBottom [...] \"Work a day\" (adjective) = mundane; common; usual; standard (of quality); \"The new cell phone is not remarkable at all, it has a workaday processor and last year's screen.\" (Often used in the phrase \"[in the] workaday world of high finance/professional football/aviation/teaching, etc, etc.\" meaning 'normal and not exciting area of activity')",
      "score": 0.059850052,
      "raw_content": null

      "title": "seeking vs. to seek - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/seeking-vs-to-seek.4076594/",
      "content": ":\n> \n> \n> \n> [_US activists organized a national strike_] [_seeking an eight-hour workday_]\n> \n> \n> [...] _US activists organized a national strike because they were seeking an eight-hour workday._​\n\n_US activists organized a national strike in order to seek an eight-hour workday._​\n\n I know that the phrase \"to seek redress\" works just fine with this structure and in sentences like \"he went to court to seek redress for his wrongful dismissal\", but here 'seek' carries a slightly different meaning than in the OP.\n\n   Image 13: Agree\n\nReactions:Joetofu\n\nImage 14: 如沐春风\n\n#### 如沐春风\n\n##### Senior Member [...] Thank you sincerely for your expert knowledge and convincing explanation And your patience.🌹🌹👍👍\n\nYou must log in or register to reply here.\n\nShare:\n\nBlueskyLinkedInWhatsAppEmailShareLink\n\n   English Only\n   English Only\n\n   WR styleSystemLightDark  \n   English (EN-us)\n\n   Contact us\n   Terms and rules\n   Privacy policy\n   Help\n   RSS\n\nCommunity platform by XenForo®© 2010-2025 XenForo Ltd.\n\nBack\n\nTopBottom",

      "title": "I will shut up now vs I'll be shutting up now - WordReference...",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/i-will-shut-up-now-vs-ill-be-shutting-up-now.4008014/",
      "content": "> Roxxxannne said:\n>\n> I will/I'll [verb] and I'll be [verb]-ing are both American, but I will/I'll [verb] is more common. I think the use of I'll be [verb]-ing depends on the verb. For instance, I'll be leaving now is used fairly often compared to I'll leave now.  \n>    \n>  I've never heard anyone say I'll be shutting up now to refer to not talking. I can imagine a manager of a store saying it at the end of the workday, though.\n>\n> Click to expand... [...] > Click to expand... [...] I will/I'll [verb] and I'll be [verb]-ing are both American, but I will/I'll [verb] is more common. I think the use of I'll be [verb]-ing depends on the verb. For instance, I'll be leaving now is used fairly often compared to I'll leave now.   \n   \n I've never heard anyone say I'll be shutting up now to refer to not talking. I can imagine a manager of a store saying it at the end of the workday, though.\n\n#### kentix\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - U.S.\n\n #10",

{
  "query": "Workday Skills Cloud AI roadmap",
  "follow_up_questions": null,

  "results": [
    {
      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-us/workday-leader-gartner-mq-financial-planning-fourth-year.html",
      "title": "Workday Named a Leader in the Gartner Magic Quadrant ...",
      "content": "At Workday, we’ve deeply invested in AI, but not just for automation’s sake. Our approach is fundamentally human-centered and AI-augmented. We’re removing the massive, repetitive grind of data access, modeling, and consolidation, freeing up FP&A teams to focus on their most critical task: steering the business. The modern experience we deliver is intuitive and brings intelligence directly into planning, empowering every user to communicate and collaborate directly in context with the data. [...] This is why we continue to execute on a vision that goes beyond simple automation. We’re focused on providing predictive, personalized guidance to every decision-maker across the business so they can help their organizations grow.\n\nWe’re excited about the next era of enterprise planning, one driven by agentic AI and a truly connected approach.     {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# workday, working day\n\n Thread starter belissimo\n Start date\n\n#### belissimo\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nRussia, Moscow\n\nRussian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n If these words are synonyms,  \n which of them is the most used:workday or working day?  \n Thanks\n\nM\n\n#### mgcrules\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - Australia\n\n #2\n\nwork day is more common for me.\n\n#### belissimo [...] In AmE, @velisarius' sentence would usually be 'must be paid within 10 business days.' But I agree with the dictionaries that say 'workday' is AmE: I have an eight-hour workday, there are only four workdays this week, etc.\n\nYou must log in or register to reply here.\n\nShare:\n\nBluesky   LinkedIn   WhatsApp   Email   Share   Link\n\n English Only\n English Only\n\nTop Bottom",

      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"\n\n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"\n\n  more commonly \"working day\".\n\n   Image 9: Agree\n\nReactions:futursimple\n\nImage 10: KHS\n\n#### KHS [...] \"Work a day\" (adjective) = mundane; common; usual; standard (of quality); \"The new cell phone is not remarkable at all, it has a workaday processor and last year's screen.\" (Often used in the phrase \"[in the] workaday world of high finance/professional football/aviation/teaching, etc, etc.\" meaning 'normal and not exciting area of activity') [...] ##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\n USA - English L1 \n\n   Dec 30, 2014\n\n   \n\n   Contact us\n   Terms and rules\n   Privacy policy\n   Help\n   RSS\n\nCommunity platform by XenForo®© 2010-2025 XenForo Ltd.\n\nBack\n\nTopBottom",
      "score": 0.048266806,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "title": "on the workday - WordReference Forums",

Most workers get several hours leisure time even on workdays, before and after work.\n\nImage 5: Kacy.H\n\n#### Kacy.H\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nChina\n\n Chinese \n\n   Dec 8, 2018\n\n   \n\n   Contact us\n   Terms and rules\n   Privacy policy\n   Help\n   RSS",

      "content": "Like Carolinian, I would say work day, or the closed forum workday.  \n Our dictionaries recognize this as a difference between British and American English.  \n   \n From Collins Concise English Dictionary, a British English dictionary.  \n\nworking day, esp us workday​\n\n1. a day on which work is done, esp for an agreed or stipulated number of hours in return for a salary or wage\n\nYou must log in or register to reply here.\n\nShare:\n\nBluesky   LinkedIn   WhatsApp   Email   Share   Link [...] You are using an out of date browser.     {
      "title": "jour ouvré / jour ouvrable | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/jour-ouvré-jour-ouvrable.607089/",
      "content": "workday is AE, then (I didn't know that)  \n   \n I believe we would only say a working day for a day when you you choose or are assigned to work (if you don't have a standard Mon-Fri work assignment).  \n   \n Next week Saturday is a working day (or workday) for me, so I can't play golf then. Si j'ai bien compris l'exemple donné par staarkali, ça pourrait être l'équivalent de jour ouvré. [...] I also say workday, for jour ouvrable, though I don't mind working day. But jour ouvrable suivant = next business day. I thik business day is mostly used for commerce and finance.   \n   \n Now - as already suggested - there is a difference to be made between jour ouvré and jour ouvrable.   \n   \n As found in the GDT, under jour ouvrable  \n> Définition :  \n>  Jour de la semaine qui est normalement consacré au travail ou aux activités professionnelles et qui n'est pas un jour férié. [...] jour ouvrable / jour de travail = workday/working day  \n jour ouvré / jour travaillé = day worked\n\n#### Staarkali\n\n##### Senior Member\n\n上海，Shanghai\n\nFrance\n\n #7\n\nthanks for all these answers; to sum up, it appears that:  \n for jour ouvrable, workday apparently best fits the bill, but working day and business day may works as well  \n for jour ouvré, day worked might be the only choice\n\n#### broglet\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nLondon\n\nEnglish - England\n\n #8",

      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/difference-between-working-days-and-weekdays.2566775/",
      "content": "aren't counted in 'working days'. [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"\n\n Thread starter annjuks\n Start date\n\nA\n\n#### annjuks\n\n##### Member\n\nLatvia\n\nLatvian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n What's the difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"? Is the second one used more frequently than the first? (In the examples like \"the centre is open on working days/ weekdays\")\n\nLast edited: [...] Yes, weekdays are the days from Monday to Friday, as opposed to the weekend. This is the usual expression if you mean those five days. We'd talk about working days only if there was a possibility of them being different - so 'working days' excludes public holidays. A bank might guarantee to clear a cheque (put the money in your account) within three working days. So if you put it in on the Thursday the day before Easter, you might not get the money for almost a week, because the Easter holidays",
      "score": 0.035320852,

[...] “To give you an idea, there’s two live regions today. We’ve announced that there’ll be 20 more coming soon. We’re out with 19c and then, of course, just updated to 26ai,” Thomas said. “Customers are just consistently saying that they’re excited about taking that mission-critical data set they’ve had in the Oracle databases and starting to leverage it for AI data pipelines and being able to use it with all of the [applications].” [...] “[It’s the] same mentality of saying, yeah, you can get Exadata, you can get Autonomous Database, you get all of our [Autonomous Recovery Services] systems for recovery, you get all of the same migration capabilities [and] zero downtime migration capabilities,” he explained. “And now things like Autonomous AI Lakehouse, it’s all the same set of tech.       "content": "Document AI Enterprise Knowledge Graph\n\n用途\n\n用途\n\n### Google AI 網誌：從範本文件擷取結構化資料\n\nDocument AI\n\n用途\n\n用途\n\n### 客戶可透過 Document AI 解決方案縮短文件處理時間並降低成本，現已正式發布\n\nDocument AI 最新版本是由 Google 累積數十年的 AI 創新技術所打造而成，能為這些挑戰提供強大且實用的解決方案。\n\nDocument AI 採購 貸款\n\n用途\n\n用途\n\n### 邁向國際：Workday 運用 Google Cloud AI 加快文件處理作業\n\n每天要處理數百萬份文件，而且業務遍及全球，要擴大規模並不容易。Workday 擁有超過 3,400 位核心 Workday Financial Management 和 Workday HCM 客戶，並提供 Workday Expenses 解決方案，為客戶提供順暢的費用報告體驗。瞭解他們如何運用 Google Cloud 的採購文件專用 Document AI 達成目標。\n\nDocument AI 採購\n\n用途 [...] 透過 Google Cloud 的運算解決方案和 Document AI，您可以為使用者建立無縫整合且易於使用的應用程式。Document AI 是一項平台和一系列解決方案，可協助企業將文件轉換為以機器學習為基礎的結構化資料。在本網誌文章中，我們將逐步說明如何使用無伺服器技術，透過 Cloud Functions 處理文件，並透過 Workflows 協調微服務、API 呼叫和函式，進而處理業務流程。\n\nDocument AI 工作流程\n\n訓練\n\n訓練與教學課程\n\n### 使用 Document AI 深入瞭解文件內容\n\n我們最近宣布 Document AI Platform 正式推出。這項 Google 解決方案可自動處理及驗證文件，進而簡化文件工作流程。重要的商家資料不一定會以電腦可讀取的格式提供。這類格式包括 PDF、手寫表單和圖片等。\n\nDocument AI\n\n訓練\n\n訓練與教學課程\n\n### 使用 Document AI 將採購工作流程自動化 [...] 我們最近宣布 Document AI Platform 正式推出。這項 Google 解決方案可自動處理及驗證文件，進而簡化文件工作流程。重要的商家資料不一定會以電腦可讀取的格式提供。這類格式包括 PDF、手寫表單和圖片等。\n\nDocument AI\n\n訓練\n\n訓練與教學課程\n\n### 使用 Google Cloud 建構文件理解管道\n\n文件解讀是指使用 AI 和機器學習技術，從電子郵件、PDF、掃描文件等文字和紙本來源中擷取資料和洞察資訊。過去，擷取這類非結構化或「暗資料」的過程既耗時又所費不貲，而且容易出錯，需要手動輸入資料。如今，AI 和機器學習技術在自動化這項程序方面已取得重大進展，讓企業能夠從先前未開發的資料中取得洞察資訊並加以運用。\n\nDocument AI AutoML Vision AutoML Natural Language\n\n訓練\n\n訓練與教學課程\n\n### 使用 Document AI 大規模自動擷取資料",

      "content": "Before using the Asana connector, do the following tasks:\n\n In your Google Cloud project:\n  + Ensure that network connectivity is set up. If you don't have a service account, you must create a service account. The connector and the service account must belong to the same project. For more information, see Creating a service account.\n  + Enable the following services:\n    - `secretmanager.googleapis.com` (Secret Manager API)",
      "score": 0.047148798,
      "raw_content": null

      "content": "A service account is a special type of Google account intended to represent a non-human user that needs to authenticate and be authorized to access data in Google APIs.       "content": "Generative AI and the SBO  \nGenerative AI is rapidly becoming the cognitive engine of the SBO. It doesn’t just automate skill tagging or matching – it continuously senses, interprets and predicts workforce capabilities in motion. By mapping emerging skills to evolving work, GenAI enables organizations to dynamically design roles, personalize learning and anticipate workforce shifts. [...] But AI’s power only translates into impact when it fuels a connected skills intelligence ecosystem that blends skills data from learning, talent acquisition and performance systems. GenAI provides the intelligence layer, and human judgment provides the wisdom layer. Human capability isn’t replaced but amplified, as static job data feeds a living, learning skills network. [...] Existing HR suites are increasingly including skills functionalities, making the need to move to skills-specialized solutions less urgent. Comparing those suites to point solutions, we’ve found that specific skills functionalities are better in tools from vendors like Eightfold, SkyHive, Gloat, Fuel50, Retrain.ai and TechWolf, but they add integration complexity.       "content": "Get Workday data into Snowflake using Report-as-a-Service (RaaS) streams for enterprise-level analytics and planning\n\n## Limitations¶\n\n Only advanced Workday reports are supported.\n Only reports in the JSON format are supported.\n All limitations of the RaaS API apply.\n The schema discovery is not supported - schema of a destination table\n  is inferred based on data fetched from Workday.\n The incremental load is not supported - the connector uses the\n  truncate & load ingestion strategy. [...] # About Openflow Connector for Workday¶\n\nNote\n\nThis connector is subject to the Snowflake Connector Terms.\n\nThe Openflow Connector for Workday allows to ingest Workday reports into\nSnowflake. It is built as the Apache NiFi flow and uses the RaaS\n(Report-as-a-Service) API to fetch data from Workday. The connector\npersists data in a dedicated table in the database and schema provided\nin the configuration.\n\nUse this connector if you’re looking to do the following: [...] More information",

[...] While most industries and corporate functions have already undergone substantial technology-driven transformation, legal has remained relatively untouched due to the unstructured nature of legal data and the continued reliance on expert professionals.       "content": "Chapter 3 looks at the need for speed and safety in AI deployment. While leaders and employees want to move faster, trust and safety are top concerns. About half of employees worry about AI inaccuracy and cybersecurity risks. That said, employees express greater confidence that their own companies, versus other organizations, will get AI right. The onus is on business leaders to prove them right, by making bold and responsible decisions. [...] Our research looked at people who self-identify as “Zoomers,” “Bloomers,” “Gloomers,” and “Doomers” in their attitudes toward AI—a set of archetypes introduced in Superagency. We find that 39 percent of employees identify as Bloomers, who are AI optimists that want to collaborate with their companies to create responsible solutions. Meanwhile, 37 percent identify as Gloomers, who are more skeptical about AI and want extensive top-down AI regulations; 20 percent identify as Zoomers, who want AI [...] Chapter 5 looks at what is required for leaders to set their teams up for success with AI.     {
      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/governance-security-across-organization",
      "title": "Governance and security for AI agents across the ...",
      "content": "All agents must comply with Responsible AI policies. Corporate compliance ensures agents align with internal governance policies. These policies include consistent deployment practices, version control, and guardrails across environments. Define reusable infrastructure templates and mandate their use. Use policy-as-code and infrastructure-as-code to enforce standards. Review agent updates and deployments through automated pipelines. [...] 3. Standardize internal access controls. Internal-facing agents follow the same data governance rules as other systems. Agents retrieve data that the requesting user has authorization to access. Pass the user's identity or token securely when querying data, ensuring session integrity and least privilege. For example, an internal helpdesk agent shows an employee only their own HR record, not someone else's. Align agent behavior with existing role-based access controls to maintain compliance and [...] 5. Standardize data integrations. Standardize how agents connect to knowledge and tools to reduce duplication and simplify maintenance. Use official APIs and connectors instead of custom integrations. Multiple agents across departments (IT, HR, facilities) reuse infrastructure, reduce operational costs, and accelerate deployment timelines. Support agents with a shared knowledge base for company policies. When integrating knowledge and tools, follow governance policies that use project-level",

      "content": "“Bias in employment arising from the use of algorithms and AI falls squarely within the Commission’s priority to address systemic discrimination,” Burrows said. “While the technology may be evolving, anti-discrimination laws still apply. The EEOC will address workplace bias that violates federal civil rights laws regardless of the form it takes, and the agency is committed to helping employers understand how to benefit from these new technologies while also complying with employment laws.” [...] Establish an internal working group to coordinate the agency’s work on the initiative;\n   Launch a series of listening sessions with key stakeholders about algorithmic tools and their employment ramifications;\n   Gather information about the adoption, design, and impact of hiring and other employment-related technologies;\n   Identify promising practices; and\n   Issue technical assistance to provide guidance on algorithmic fairness and the use of AI in employment decisions. [...] “Artificial intelligence and algorithmic decision-making tools have great potential to improve our lives, including in the area of employment,” Burrows said. “At the same time, the EEOC is keenly aware that these tools may mask and perpetuate bias or create new discriminatory barriers to jobs. We must work to ensure that these new technologies do not become a high-tech pathway to discrimination.”",

      "content": "The move towards monitoring HR tools and applications for bias is gaining traction worldwide, driven by various global and domestic data privacy laws and the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). In line with this trend, the New York City Council has enacted new regulations requiring organizations to conduct yearly bias audits on automated employment decision-making tools used by HR departments. [...] The new rules, which passed in December 2021 with enforcement, will require organizations that use algorithmic HR tools to conduct a yearly bias audit. As per the new law, noncompliant organizations may face fines ranging from no less than USD 500 to no more than USD 1500 for each violation.\n\nTo prepare for this shift, some organizations are developing a yearly evaluation, mitigation, and review process. Here’s a suggestion for how that might work in practice.\n\n## Step one – Evaluate [...] As governments around the world implement regulations regarding the use of AI and automation, organizations should evaluate and revise their processes to address compliance with new regulations. [...] The EEOC under Lucas has since removed some AI-related documents while it reviews them in line with a Trump order that revoked Biden administration-era AI policies. The Trump administration is unlikely to prioritize disparate impact claims related to AI discrimination, and a recent memo from the attorney general directed the DOJ to limit the use of disparate impact theories.\n\nDEI Programs [...] In the meantime, the EEOC is declining to enforce the harassment guidance by dismissing its own lawsuits alleging sexual orientation and gender identity discrimination filed under the Biden administration. [...] Although no federal law specifically addresses the use of AI in the employment context (yet), discrimination is already prohibited by Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act and a host of other federal, state and local laws.\n\nAs such, preventing algorithmic bias is essential regardless of the outcome of pending AI legislation.",

      "content": "In an HR context, biased AI algorithms used for resume screening may favor candidates from certain demographic backgrounds, leading to a lack of diversity in hiring practices.\n In the finance sector, AI systems used for credit scoring may inadvertently disadvantage individuals from minority groups due to historical data reflecting systemic inequalities, resulting in fewer loan approvals for these applicants. [...] 2. Algorithmic bias: Algorithmic bias arises from the design and implementation of algorithms themselves. Even with unbiased data, the way algorithms process information can introduce bias. For instance, if an algorithm is optimized for efficiency without considering fairness, it may prioritize certain outcomes over others, resulting in discriminatory practices. [...] Bias in AI systems refers to systematic and unfair discrimination that arises from the design, development and deployment of AI technologies. It can manifest in various forms, including algorithmic bias, data bias and human bias, leading to outcomes that disproportionately affect certain groups of people based on characteristics such as race, gender, age or socioeconomic status.",

      "content": "“Enforcement Guidance on Harassment in the Workplace” was “approved by the Commission on April 29, 2024, by a 3-2 vote” and that “any modification must be approved by a majority vote of the Commission.” Without a quorum, this guidance – and all other formal EEOC guidance – remains effectively frozen in place. [...] A critical distinction exists between formal guidance and EEOC “technical assistance.” While formal guidance requires Commission approval, technical assistance documents fall solely under the Chair's authority and can be issued or revoked without a Commission vote. [...] The practical impact of this distinction became immediately apparent on January 27, 2025, when numerous EEOC technical assistance documents quietly disappeared from the agency's website. This swift action under Acting Chair Lucas's authority resulted in the removal of several significant documents from the EEOC’s website: all technical assistance regarding artificial intelligence and its intersection with the ADA and Title VII, the agency's report on technology sector discrimination, its",

      "title": "Example of Use Cases - AIRC",
      "url": "https://airc.nist.gov/airmf-resources/usecases/",
      "content": "While NIST does not validate or endorse any individual organization or its approach to using the AI RMF, below we provide documented usecases of the NIST AI RMF being put into action. NIST encourages industry, civil society, academia, and government stakeholders to submit additional usecases to  AIframework@nist.gov  .\n\n## Government\n\n ### City of San Jose, CA use case and Playbook\n\n  + City of San Jose, CA\n ### PEAT AI Hiring Framework [...] The voluntary NIST AI Risk Management Framework was developed through a collaborative process by industry, civil society, academia, and government stakeholders.\n\nThe Framework is designed to equip organizations and individuals with approaches that increase the trustworthiness of AI systems, and to help foster their responsible design, development, and deployment.     {
      "title": "Roadmap for the NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk Management ...",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/roadmap-nist-artificial-intelligence-risk-management-framework-ai",
      "content": "6. Development of case studies about how the AI RMF has been used by a single organization or sector, context, or AI actor. Use cases may be similar to AI RMF profiles but can more directly describe organizational experiences and challenges using the AI RMF – and how they were addressed – along with information about resources, timeframes, and AI RMF effectiveness. [...] The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society to implement the approaches in the Framework. The AI RMF is designed to equip organizations and individuals – AI actors – with approaches that increase the trustworthiness of AI systems. [...] 3. AI RMF 1.0 Profiles. Profiles are a primary method for organizations to share real-life examples of how they put the AI RMF into practice. These profiles can be for a given industry sector (such as hiring, criminal justice, lending), cross-sectoral (such as large language models, cloud-based services or acquisition), temporal (such as current vs desired state), or other topics. Organizations and individuals are encouraged to jointly or independently produce AI RMF profiles.",

      "title": "AI Risk Management Framework | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework",
      "content": ". The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] A companion NIST AI RMF Playbookalso has been published by NIST along with an AI RMF Roadmap \"),AI RMF Crosswalk \"),and various Perspectives.\n\nOn March 30, 2023, NIST launched the Trustworthy and Responsible AI Resource Center, which will facilitate implementation of, and international alignment with, the AI RMF. Examples of how other organizations are building on and using the AI RMF can be found via the AIRC’s Use Case page. [...] On July 26, 2024, NIST releasedNIST-AI-_600-1, Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework: Generative Artificial Intelligence Profile_. The profile can help organizations identify unique risks posed by generative AI and proposes actions for generative AI risk management that best aligns with their goals and priorities.\n\nTo view public comments received on the previous drafts of the AI RMF and Requests for Information, see theAI RMF Developmentpage.\n\nTranslations",

    {
      "title": "NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF)",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/system/files/documents/2024/10/07/09-24-about-the-ai-rmf-for-distro-9-25_508-edit.pdf",
      "content": "Develop AI RMF profiles. These can be either use case profiles (e.g., hiring) or temporal profiles (e.g., describing how an organization can move from its current state to its target state in managing AI risks). Translate the AI RMF into additional languages.\nContribute additional AI RMF crosswalks. [...] NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) Development of the AI RMF About The AI RMF May 2025 Developed following the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P .L. 116-283), NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is a voluntary framework to help individuals, organizations, and society manage AI’s risks and promote trustworthy development and responsible use of AI systems. Enhancements will be added to the accompanying Playbook to make the AI RMF more [...] Actions You Can Take The framework provides implementation flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society. Released in January 2023, the AI RMF is intended to build on, align with, and support AI risk management efforts by others.\n• A NIST AI RMF Playbook suggests ways to navigate and use the AI RMF to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems.",
      "score": 0.75290436,

    {
      "title": "Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework ... - NIST",
      "url": "https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ai/NIST.AI.600-1.pdf",
      "content": "cases or sectors, this document is an AI RMF cross-sectoral proﬁle. Cross-sectoral proﬁles can be used to govern, map, measure, and manage risks associated with activities or business processes common across sectors, such as the use of large language models (LLMs), cloud-based services, or acquisition. This document deﬁnes risks that are novel to or exacerbated by the use of GAI. After introducing and describing these risks, the document provides a set of suggested actions to help organizations [...] or across extended periods. Examples include immediate (and/or prolonged) emotional harm and potential risks to physical safety due to the distribution of harmful deepfake images, or the long-term eﬀect of disinformation on societal trust in public institutions. The presence of risks and where they fall along the dimensions above will vary depending on the characteristics of the GAI model, system, or use case at hand. These characteristics include but are not limited to GAI model or system [...] Scope: Risks may exist at individual model or system levels, at the application or implementation levels (i.e., for a speciﬁc use case), or at the ecosystem level – that is, beyond a single system or organizational context. Examples of the latter include the expansion of “algorithmic monocultures,3” resulting from repeated use of the same model, or impacts on access to opportunity, labor markets, and the creative economies.4 • Source of risk: Risks may emerge from factors related to the design,",
      "score": 0.7190094,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1",
      "url": "https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ai/NIST.AI.100-1.pdf",
      "content": "Page 7 NIST AI 100-1 AI RMF 1.0 When applying the AI RMF, risks which the organization determines to be highest for the AI systems within a given context of use call for the most urgent prioritization and most thorough risk management process. In cases where an AI system presents unacceptable negative risk levels – such as where significant negative impacts are imminent, severe harms are actually occurring, or catastrophic risks are present – development and deployment should cease in a safe [...] As directed by the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P.L. 116-283), the goal of the AI RMF is to offer a resource to the organizations designing, developing, deploying, or using AI systems to help manage the many risks of AI and promote trustwor-thy and responsible development and use of AI systems. The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector-specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibil-ity to organizations of all sizes and in all [...] management may depend on existing guidelines for specific applications and use case settings. Where established guidelines do not exist, organizations should define reasonable risk tolerance. Once tolerance is defined, this AI RMF can be used to manage risks and to document risk management processes.",

      "content": "The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society to implement the approaches in the Framework. The AI RMF is designed to equip organizations and individuals – AI actors – with approaches that increase the trustworthiness of AI systems . [...] NIST has preparedseveral crosswalksto the Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0). As directed by the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P.L. 116-283), the goal of the AI RMF is to offer a voluntary resource to the organizations designing, developing, deploying, or using AI systems to help manage the many risks of AI and promote trustworthy and responsible development and use of AI systems. [...] The Framework is intended for use with, and to encourage the development of other AI resources, including guidance and standards. The NIST Roadmap for the AI RMF cites alignment with international standards as a top priority for the agency and the AI community.\n\nComments on these crosswalks and suggestions for additional crosswalks are welcomed by NIST at any time and should be addressed to AIframework [at] nist.gov (AIframework[at]nist[dot]gov).",

    {
      "title": "NIST AI RMF Playbook | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has created a companion AI RMF playbookfor voluntary use – which suggests ways to navigate and use the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems. [...] The AI RMF and the Playbook are intended for voluntary use. Organizations may utilize this information by borrowing as many – or as few – suggestions as apply to their industry use case or interests.\n\nPlaybook content will evolve to enable community review and feedback about its informativeness, accuracy and specificity. The first complete version announced on March 30, 2023, includes options for filtering or tailoring information to user preferences and requirements. [...] The Playbook is based on AI RMF 1.0 (released on January 26, 2023). It includes suggested actions, references, and related guidance to achieve the outcomes for the four functions in the AI RMF: Govern, Map, Measure, and Manage. Playbook suggestions are developed based on best practices and research insights.",
      "score": 0.70336664,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "AI RMF Resources - AIRC",
      "url": "https://airc.nist.gov/airmf-resources/",
      "content": "The AI RMF Core provides outcomes and actions that enable dialogue, understanding, and activities to manage AI risks and responsibility develop trustworthy AI systems. This is operationalized through four functions: Govern, Map, Measure, and Manage.\n6. ## AI RMF Profiles\n\n   The use-case Profiles are implementations of the AI RMF functions, categories, and subcategories for a specific setting or application based on the requirements, risk tolerance, and resources of the Framework user. [...] The AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] As a consensus resource, the AI RMF was developed in an open, transparent, multidisciplinary, and multistakeholder manner over an 18-month time period and in collaboration with more than 240 contributing organizations from private industry, academia, civil society, and government. Feedback received during the development of the AI RMF is publicly available on the NIST website.\n\nDownload the framework\n\n1. ## Framing risk",
      "score": 0.70067,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "NIST AI RMF Playbook FAQs",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook-faqs",
      "content": "TheNIST AI RMF is a consensus-based resource intended for voluntary use in addressing risks in the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI systems. Currently in draft, the AI RMF describes why a risk management framework for AI is important, and explains the motivation for using the Framework, its scope, audience, and the framing of AI risk and trustworthiness. The draft AI RMF Core provides outcomes that promote and enable dialogue, understanding, and activities for AI risk management. [...] The NIST AI RMF Playbook can help organizations cultivate an environment focused on AI risks, and transform how they approach the development, deployment, and use of trustworthy AI technology.  Those interested in using the AI RMF functions to enhance their risk management posture can utilize suggested actions from the Playbook to fit their interests and needs. Anyone is free to repurpose portions of the Playbook to create their own internal resources or technical guidance. [...] ## AI Risk Management Framework\n\n# NIST AI RMF Playbook FAQs\n\n#### What is the purpose of the NIST AI RMF Playbook?\n\nThe NIST AI RMF Playbook is designed to inform AI actors and make the AI RMF more usable. The AI RMF Playbook provides actionable suggestions to help:",

      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/ie/en/issues/consulting/cfo-survey-autumn-winter.html",
      "title": "2025 Autumn/Winter CFO Survey",
      "content": "2. Capacity: With headcount largely flat, productivity must carry more of the growth ambition. Finance is under pressure to role model, and often lead, the use of process simplification, automation, and AI to release human capacity from routine or low value activities and focus effort on adding increased business value. The aim is not to have fewer people, it’s to deliver more business impact per euro of people spend. [...] More organisations are turning to external partners to undertake activities that do not directly support their core mission. While outsourcing has long been part of this strategy, the traditional approach which focuses primarily on labour cost savings is no longer fit for purpose. While cost savings remain important, we have observed growing disillusionment with this approach. This stems from the growing overlap between the human and digital workforce and as generative AI shifts the [...] 1. Capability: Global research suggests that roughly half of today's core skills will change within five years, with AI, data, and problem-solving capabilities in highest demand. Deloitte's recent Human Capital Trends Survey 2025 findings echo this, with many leaders doubting their recent hires are fully prepared for the work ahead. The question for finance is no longer ‘Can we hire?’ but ‘What capabilities do we need to build, buy, or borrow?’ and ‘How quickly’ to deliver business as usual",

      "title": "Microsoft Excel Powers an AI-Resistant, Multitrillion-Dollar ...",
      "content": "Ballmer retired from Microsoft in 2014 and now spends much of his time running the Los Angeles Clippers, but as if to make the point about the power of a spreadsheet demo, he pulls up one of his own Excel files—a detailed accounting, with hundreds of rows, of how he spends each hour of each workday. The spreadsheet includes the number of hours in a given month spent meeting with players, working on his nonprofits, checking emails, exercising, playing golf, getting massages and on and on. [...] Excel was born at a Microsoft offsite in 1983 under the code name Odyssey. The original plan was to create a better version of Lotus for IBM-style PCs. “In many ways it was a troubled project,” says Doug Klunder, the lead developer. From Klunder’s point of view the trouble started in 1984, when Steve Jobs unveiled Apple Inc.’s Macintosh, the first inexpensive computer with a mouse and a graphical user interface. The buzz—along with the fact that Microsoft was itself preparing to release its [...] There are reasons to be skeptical of claims that AI is killing off the spreadsheet. The chatbots’ large language models typically struggle with simple calculations, and they’re notoriously bad at showing their work. “In my day to day, I spend more time fighting off people’s vibe-coded projects than actual useful AI integrations,” says Nick Frescas, a data analytics manager who serves as a moderator for the Excel forum on Reddit under the handle Frescani. “There’s something about processing data",

      "content": "As more employers adopt artificial intelligence tools as part of the everyday workflow, AI also is creeping into a key part of employees’ lives: performance reviews.\n\nCompanies that have adopted the technology seek to make the process easier, particularly for managers who might otherwise have to track down disparate bits of information from different sources. \n\nBut it’s not as easy as telling managers and workers that it’s OK to start using ChatGPT. [...] “This exposes employers to Title VII, ADA and Age Discrimination in Employment Act claims,” he said. “Even ‘neutral’ algorithms can create disparate impact if they disadvantage protected groups.” He added that even if the AI tool is from a third-party vendor, it doesn’t protect an employer from liability. [...] Data privacy should be a concern as well: “AI tools designed to enhance performance reviews may rely on the use of personal employee information and any misuse could subject the organization to privacy related claims, including those arising from information security breaches,” he said, plus “employees may have rights to know how their data is used in the context of employer conducted performance reviews.”\n\n purchase licensing rights\n\nFiled Under: Talent,  HR Tech & Analytics",

This shift requires teams to retool and learn new capabilities, because AI augments work and cannot replace human judgment, which remains essential for interpretation and governance. If successful, the case could shift liability from individual employers to the vendors that build and operate AI tools.       "content": "UPDATED 09:15 EST / JUNE 03 2025\n\n### Workday launches AI agent developer toolset with third-party connector and custom widgets\n\nby  Kyt Dotson\n\nEnterprise management software company Workday Inc. today unveiled a new unified developer toolset for building artificial intelligence apps and agents on its platform. [...] With the new AI Agent Gateway developers will be able to connect third-party agents to the Workday Agent System of Record, a platform the company launched in February aimed at helping businesses onboard agents and treat them like any new piece of software. At the time the company said businesses were facing an unprecedented influx of AI agents from all corners that were serving to solve numerous use cases, but didn’t have a good way to manage them. [...] Announced during the company’s annual developer conference Workday DevCon 2025 in Las Vegas, the new toolset includes an Agent Gateway that will provide connectors for third-party AI agents and for agent-to-agent collaboration, AI widgets and expanded application programming interfaces for native integration into AI apps.",

      "content": "The two organizations share a vision, added Gerrit Kazmaier, president of product and technology at Workday. “AI is not a single vendor solution. I think AI actually is not even a vendor solution. It’s an ecosystem that emerges on shared data, shared governance and shared intelligence across a network of systems.”\n\nWith the announcement, Kazmaier said, the program enters the early adopter phase during which customers can try it out and provide feedback before it becomes generally available. [...] Melody Brue, VP and principal analyst at Moor Insights & Strategy, added, “With this deal, Microsoft gets access to Workday’s enterprise customer base for AI agent deployment, and may reduce implementation complexity for their shared customers.   "query": "site:invisors.com Workday AI",

The spreadsheet includes the number of hours in a given month spent meeting with players, working on his nonprofits, checking emails, exercising, playing golf, getting massages and on and on. [...] To help push that point, Microsoft executives planted a question about the future of Excel. During a Q&A portion of the event, a reporter asked if it would be available exclusively on the Mac, or if Microsoft planned to bring it to PCs. Gates answered diplomatically, telling the crowd his plan was to make Excel available to all platforms “in time,” according to Jeff Raikes, then a Microsoft marketing executive who attended the event. “He’s trying to be gentle with Steve Jobs,” Raikes recalls. [...] that he urged reps to “demo, demo, demo, demo, demo,” as he puts it. “You’re showing another senior person, ‘See, I use this thing. Isn’t this amazing?’”",

      "content": "We've seen this pattern before. Don't let fear hold you back, embrace the immense possibilities of AI and help shape the future of work. [...] There are also “serious legal and compliance questions that HR leaders cannot afford to ignore,” said Cassat. “While AI promises efficiency and data-driven insights, its use in evaluating employees could subject organizations to discrimination claims as well as substantial compliance obligations.”\n\nThat’s because AI systems learn from historical data, and if past reviews favored people from certain demographics, the algorithms may replicate or even amplify biases.       "title": "How HR has to lead the rise of Agentic AI",
      "content": "Nearly nine in ten HR professionals using AI in recruiting say it saves time, and more than one in three reports reduced hiring costs2. Agentic AI is already being piloted across HR, finance, technology, and other support functions. We’ve seen AI agents draft onboarding plans, schedule interviews, and even detect early signs of burnout based on behavioral signals. This evolution is well underway. [...] To unlock that value, you need strong foundations, in technology, people, policies, and purpose. Start by aligning HR, IT, legal, and business leaders around one defining question: What kind of collaborator do we want this agent to be?\n\nThis is where the real shift begins. Governance moves from compliance to design. Talent strategies expand to include reskilling programs for AI fluency. Operating models evolve to integrate AI agents at every level, not just as tools, but as contributors. [...] Success tip: Treat AI agents like internal talent. Give them a manager, performance goals, regular reviews, and a clear purpose. The more structure you provide, the more value and trust you’ll unlock.\n\n##### Busting four myths about Agentic AI\n\nUse this as a checklist to assess your readiness.
